brief_summary.textblock:
An adverse event (AE) is defined as unintended injury or complication, which results in
      disability, death or prolongation of hospital stay, and is caused by healthcare management
      (including omissions) rather than the patient's disease. Retrospective record reviews in
      several countries have shown that 2,9% to 16,6% of patients in acute hospitals experience
      one or more AEs. A patient with an AE may require a higher level of care.  Although all AEs
      are important, preventable AEs that result in an upgraded level of patient care are of
      particular concern. In this study it's defined as an unplanned admission to intensive care
      unit (ICU) or a Mobile Emergency Team (MET) intervention. The objectives of this study are
      to determine the incidence of (preventable) adverse events requiring ICU admission or MET
      intervention and to assess the level of harm of each AE.

clinical_study.brief_title: Medical Record Study on Adverse Events Requiring a Higher Level of Care in Flemish Hospitals
clinical_study.condition: Sepsis, Cancer, Heart Attack, Heart Failure, Abdominal Surgery, Trauma, Diabetes, Lung Disease, Gynaecology, Fertility, Cardiac Surgery,

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  All patients being transferred to a higher level of care during the study period
             (November 2011 - May 2012)

          -  In practice, the higher level of care means

          -  (1) (re)admission to the Intensive Care Unit from other care units in the hospital
             providing lower intensity care,

          -  (2) to an intervention by a Medical Emergency Team due to an unanticipated change in
             the patient's clinical status

        Exclusion Criteria:

        -

clinical_study.official_title: Medical Record Study on Adverse Events Requiring a Higher Level of Care in Flemish Hospitals

primary_outcome.description: An adverse event is an unintended injury or complication, which results in disability at discharge, death or prolongation of hospital stay, and is caused by healthcare management (including omissions) rather than the patient's disease. (Wilson, 1995)
primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of adverse events requiring a higher level of care

primary_outcome.description: Assess the preventability of these adverse events using six point scale with a range of not preventable until totally preventable
primary_outcome.measure: The number of participants with preventable adverse events

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Divide the adverse events into categories, like diagnosis, therapy, medication, surgery, non-surgery, etc.
Assess the impact of the adverse events in terms of disability, mortality, readmission.
secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical impact of adverse events in terms of outcome

secondary_outcome.description: The patient chart will be judge on the completeness and adequacy

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Retrospective
